 Abstract What are the population growth consequences of public policies and programs to reduce mortality? How large a change in growth will result from efforts to lower fertility? An adequate response to such questions requires an approach which begins with the programs and policies under consideration and examines their overall influence on fertility and mortality. There are two types of influence to be covered: first, the influence of the policies or programs in question on mor- tality and on fertility; and second, the influence of the resulting fertility or mortality decline on the rate of change in the other. Current approaches, which focus primarily on the growth consequences of a change in mortality or fertility per se, largely overlook the former of these two types of influence. This makes them inadequate for the assessment of public policies and programs, especially for the assessment of the many poli- cies and programs undertaken for the purpose of reducing mortality or fer- tility which have a strong direct impact on the other as well. An approach of the sort required is more difficult to apply than to espouse. But its potential significance for policy and program analysis can be illustrated through a few qualitative and crude quantitative examples. These illustrations, taken in conjunction with the conceptual considerations pre- sented, suggest two propositions to serve as interim guides to action and as hypotheses to be confirmed or disproven through future research: -- Most programs and polices undertaken to reduce mortality will, in most settings and over the long run, produce even larger fertility declines and thus slower growth. -- Most measures designed to reduce fertility will also result in slower growth, but by an amount that may upon occasion be significantly less than anticipated on the basis on conventional assessment techniques.  Introduction A great deal of work has gone into exploring the influence of mortality reduction on fertility and on population growth. A comparable amount of effort has been devoted to demonstrating the population growth implications of faster fertility decline. The quality of this research has often been impressive, and its findings have frequently been illuminating. Its results, however, can be misleading. For the population growth consequences of a mortality or fertility change per se are not necessarily the same as - and might well, under some circum- stances, be quite different from -- the population growth implications of the policy or program producing that change, because of other demographic effects produced by the policy'and program in question. What matters from a public policy perspective is the overall impact of measures available for consideration or under implementation rather than the effects of only one of the changes resulting from them. An adequate appre- ciation of the population growth implications of public efforts will thus require movement away from the present focus on the growth impact of a mor- tality or fertility change per se, toward a broader assessment that starts with the programs and policies responsible for that mortality or fertility change. What follows represents an intial effort in this direction. It is to proceed in the three stages. The first will feature a presentation of the
 -2- approach to be advanced, along with an explanation of how it differs from and why it appears preferable to those currently in use. The second stage will consist of a discussion of two prominent recent policy and program proposals -- one for reducing fertility, the other for reducing mortality -- a discussion designed to show how an assessment of the proposals' population growth implications would be affected by using the approach being advanced in place of those currently in use. Third will come an extension of the qualita- tive presentation of part two by means of a few elementary, crude quantitative illustrations. This will be followed by a brief summary and word of encour- agement to anyone interested in undertaking the much more careful quantitative work that will be required if the full demographic impacts of fertilty and mortality measures are to be adequately appreciated. I. Model C is that to be advanced as more appropriate. The Models in Brief Model A has the initial decline in mortality as its starting point. According to it, mortality decline affects population growth in two ways. Mortality decline, especially infant mortality decline, produces a reduction in fer- tility by extending the period of lactation and by reducing the number of births required for a couple to produce a given number of surviving offspring. This fertility decline, which tends to reduce population growth, represents a countervailing pressure to that produced by the mortality decline's more direct growth influence. The amount of work being undertaken within the framework of this model is voluminous. Of special concern has been a delineation and assessment of the mechanisms through which infant mortality decline leads to a reduction of fer- tility: the separation of the physiological from the behavioral; the division of the behavioral into "replacement" and "insurance" or "hoarding" effects; the measurement of the quantitative significance of each. Of equal interest to researchers has been the overall size of the indirect relative to the direct influences of mortality decline on population growth: whether, in par- ticular, the influence of infant mortality reductions on fertility is large enough to offset fully the pressure for faster population growth those reduc- tions also generate.l/ Model B -- if the term "model" can appropriately be applied to something so simple as two boxes connected by an arrow -- is even more straightforward than model A. It begins with fertility decline, which is translated directly into slower population growth. Model B is simpler than model A because it lacks provision for an indirect effect on population growth via mortality reduction. The implicit assumption is that faster fertility decline does not affect the rate of mortality decline.
 -5- This is the model behind the standard approach used in hundreds of popu- lation projection exercises undertaken to demonstrate the influence of faster fertility decline: exercises featuring variations in the rate of fertility decline while leaving the rate of mortality decline unchanged in order to pro- duce alternate projections of population size whose differences are attribu- table to differences in the path of fertility alone.!/ This approach has also been taken in presenting the results produced by many well-known demographic- economic models designed to demonstrate the influence of faster fertility decline and slower population growth on economic output.AI As abstractions, both models A and B are quite valid. And as such, they have proven to be of great value in pointing to features of demographic change that would not otherwise be intuitively obvious.5/ They are not, however, adequate for policy or program analysis. They would be satisfactory for this purpose only if mortality and fertility declines could be made to happen exogenously -- if policy makers could simply wish them into being. But this is not possible. Those who desire changes must put into effect policies and programs to produce them; and these policies and programs have demographic consequences that can be considerably wider than those captured by models A and B. And this means results that could be correspondingly different. Thus model C, designed to capture these other consequences. As can be seen, both models A and B are contained in it, but it is broader than either. In particular, model C starts with a policy, program, or other development leading to a change in mortality and/or fertility, rather than with the mor- tality or fertility change itself. And it examines simultaneously the mor-
 -6- tality and fertility effects of the policy, program, or development under examination in assessing its significance for growth../ The Models and Mortality Reduction Measures Model C provides two channels whereby activities undertaken for the pur- pose of reducing mortality can influence fertility. The indirect channel of model C, which operates via the mortality reduction produced, is the same as the single channel of model A. But in addition to the indirect channel, model C incorporates a further, largely overlooked direct channel7/ whereby mor- tality reduction policies and programs can influence fertility by inducing changes in attitudes and behavior in ways that are largely independent of whatever mortality reduction might be achieved. This second channel is incorporated in recognition of the importance of the direct fertility reduction influence exercised by many measures frequently discussed in terms of their mortality impact.!/ An example is women's educa- tion, which has been closely linked with reductions in infant mortality.9/ For every point of infant mortality reduction attributable to improved mater- nal education, there would be the indirect impact on fertility described above with respect to both models A and C, an impact presumably equal in magnitude to that produced by a comparably large infant mortality reduction resulting from any other measure. But, as is well known, women's education can also affect fertility directly: by delaying marriage to permit the completion of schooling, for example; through increasing women's qualifications for jobs outside the home that can compete with child-bearing as a means of gaining satisfaction and status; by enhancing the likelihood that the lower family size ideals cof younger women will prevail over those of older generations..LO/
 -7- Such effects would produce additional downward pressure on birth rates that would be ignored were only the indirect influence to be considered. To say that a direct influence can exist is not, of course, to claim that it will inevitably be important. At least some mortality reduction measures that have proven effective in the past and that are frequently mentioned as possible models for the future seem likely to exercise little if any direct impact on fertility. Examples include quasi-military approaches to malaria reduction through the application of pesticides by spraying teams from outside the villages affected, and the somewhat similar approach to vaccination and containment that worked so well against smallpox.l/ In neither case is it possible to see how the approach used might have contributed to any lasting changes in couples' attitudes or reproductive behavior other than those resulting from the mortality decline that occurred. The strength of the direct fertility influence thus seems likely to vary greatly from measure to measure; and because of this, the use of model C implies that the magnitude of fertility decline associated with any given amount of mortality reduction is not fixed. Under model A, whose only channel of influence on fertility flows from mortality decline to fertility, there is little room for variability: a ten-point infant mortality decline is a ten- point decline, regardless of how produced. But when the possibility of a highly variable direct influence is added, the picture changes. The amount of fertility decline per unit of mortality reduction becomes a function of the measures or developments by which the mortality reduction in question is pro- duced.
 -8- The Models and Fertility Reduction Measures Model C also provides two channels through which measures initiated in order to reduce fertility can lower mortality as well. The first channel is direct, analogous to that discussed earlier with respect to the effect of mor- tality reduction measures on fertility. The second channel is indirect, per- mitting the fertility reduction achieved to exercise an effect on mortality decline. This effect, comparable to the much-discussed influence of mortality reduction on fertility, has been curiously ignored in quantitative assessments of fertility reduction's population growth implications despite the publicity that family planning advocates give to fertility reduction's health and mor- tality benefits. The first of these two channels is intended to account for the propensity of many -- although not necessarily alL2/ - fertility reduction approaches to act directly on mortality as well.L3/ An example is income distribution, whose relationship with fertility has been widely discussed.iL4/ Because of the non-linearity of the income-fertility relationship, it is often argued that a pattern of development featuring faster improvements at lower rather than at higher income levels will produce a greater impact on fertility than a pattern where the largest gains are enjoyed by the better-off. To think in terms of non-linearities with respect only to fertility, though, would obviously be a mistake. For they exist at least equally clearly if not even more clearly with respect to mortality. It is well established that the poor will spend a much larger proportion of any income increment on basic com- modities reLevant for health than will the rich, thus implying that income channeled to the poor will produce a commensurately greater impact on mortality. 5/
 -9- The second, indirect channel is designed to account for well-known change in mortality that can be produced by fertility reduction per se. Fertility reduction can be expected to result in a mortality decline when the fertility reduction occurs through particularly large declines in births with a higher- than-average risk of early death and/or through a shift of births from a high- risk to a low-risk category: that is, when older women with many children are among the earliest to practice family limitation, and when birth intervals lengthenJL6/ Where this mortality impact is found, the population growth influence of fertility reduction will be diluted in the same manner that the mortality decline's impact on growth is lessened by the induced change in fer- tility. II. The Implications of Using Model C: Two Qualitative Illustrations So much for the theory. What does all this have to do with today's world and the way in which population policies and programs are shaped and assessed in it? One way of responding to such a query is to supplement the brief allu- sions to policy implications scattered through the preceding theoretical discussion with a systematic look, through the lenses of the different models presented, at the population growth implications of some measures currently being advanced to alter mortality and fertility trends. In this manner, it is possible to get a preliminary, qualitative sense of the difference that would result from applying model C rather than model A or B. Two sets of proposed measures are especially well suited for this illustrative purpose. One, concerned primarily with mortality, features pro-
 -10- posals for increasing child survival probabilities. The other consists of packages of development measures recommended for the reduction of fertility. Child Survival Programs In recent years, several international agencies have expressed interest in developing or implementing measures that would increase the likelihood of child survival. Among the best known are the World Health Organization's emphasis on primary health care, UNICEF's proposal for a "child survival revolution," and the Ford Foundation's "Child Survival/Fair Start' program..L7/ Since such interest arises primarily out of a desire to reduce mortality, the conventional way of assessing the population growth implications of programs emanating from it would be through the application of model A, with its focus on the fertility reduction resulting from whatever improvements in infant and child mortality might be produced. The use of model C's broader outlook could be expected to produce results differing in two ways from those of such a conventional approach. First, the contribution of child survival programs to fertility reduction will often be stronger. Second, the magnitude of this contribution will not be fixed but will vary according to the mix of measures employed. Because of its specificity, the UNICEF "child survival revolution" is particularly well suited to an illustration of the point. The UNICEF propos- al, first advanced in late 1982, is a package of seven measures known by the acronym "GO1BI-FFF."18/ The seven measures are: - Growth monitoring: the use of child growth charts along with regular weighing and back-up advice to help parents and health workers identify children at risk.
 -11- - Oral rehydration therapy: the oral administation of a simple solution to counter the dehydration that is the most frequent immediate cause of death resulting from diarrhea-producing infections. - Breast feeding: the promotion of awareness about the benefits of breast milk and continued reliance on it. - Immunization: the expansion of programs to vaccinate against six major communicable diseases of childhood: measles, tetanus, whooping cough, diphtheria, poliomyelitis, and tuberculosis. - Food supplements: the furnishing of extra food to poor mothers for the purpose of reducing the incidence of low birth weights, and for high-risk children at the time of weaning. - Family spacing: the provision of the knowledge and the means mothers need to lengthen the interval between births. - Female education: the improvement in the general knowledge base and status of the mother who represents, in UNICEF's terms, "the most important primary health care worker.' 1L9 / An assessment of a GOBI-FFF program implications done in terms of the conventional (model A) framework examining only the indirect effect would in all likelihood lead to the conclusion that the fertility influence is not strong enough to offset fully the change in mortality decline. For there is a general consensus among researchers that the replacement effect of mortality decline is significantly less than one-for-one; and a strong suspicion that, at least in the short run, the addition of the other indirect effects of anti- mortality measures on fertility are not large enough to make up the dif- ference. To the extent this is so, a GOBI-FFF program would be found to
 -12- produce at least some increase in population growth. The increase would not be large, to be sure, for demographic conditions are now such that even the fastest acceleration in infant child mortality decline realistically imagi- nable will produce an increment that is modest relative to that which would occur should trends continue as presently envisioned.2!0/ But however limited the difference, it would probably be found to lie in the direction of a larger rather than El smaller population size. Such a conclusion would be distinctly less likely when the examination is conducted in the context of a broader framework, like that of model C, which can accomodate the direct as well as the indirect fertility influence of GOBI-FFF program measures. For many of those measures clearly have strong direct effects. Female education's direct influence has already been described. Breast- feeding and extended birth intervals routinely figure in lists of fertility reduction approaches worthy of consideration. Such other measures as immunization, oral rehydration, and growth moni- toring would not seem necessarily to affect fertility so strongly: as suggested earlier, for example, smallpox was eradicated through an immuniza- tion program lacking immediately obvious direct fertility influence. Yet, as UNICEF discussions of the GOBI-FFF programs indicate and as others have argued, the success of such measures in the future seems likely to depend heavily upon the personal behavior of those most affected..1-/ Mothers are not likely to come or bring their children for immunizations, for example, unless they are aware that disease is caused by physiological rather than by super- natural phenomena; the success of oral rehydration or growth monitoring pro-
 -13- grams will depend heavily on the mother's awareness of how these activities can contribute. To the extent this is so, the effective implementation of such measures will require extensive educational as well as technology delivery efforts; and success will depend upon women's becoming adequately conscious and broadly "empowered" to take control of many aspects of their lives, such as fertility, in addition to being able to act effectively in areas of behavior most directly relevant for immunization, growth monitoring, and oral rehydration. This need for education may well increase the difficulty of achieving immediate mortality gains through technologically simple programs. But it also implies that any such programs which succeed will contain heavy doses of health and related education that mean the programs will exercise a much greater effect on fertility than suggested by a consideration of the programs' technological elements by themselves, pointing toward a commensurately larger amount of fertility decline per unit of mortality reduction achieved. This means that conventional assessments which ignore such direct effects clearly overstate any contribution to faster growth that GOBI-FFF programs might make. In fact, when these direct effects are added to the indirect influence noted earlier, it seems quite possible that some, perhaps many, GOBI-FFF program configurations would exercise a notably larger impact on fer- tility than on mortality, thus restraining population growth. As noted, the addition of direct effects through a more complete (model C) approach would also introduce the possibility of a variable mortality- fertility relationship, rather than the fixed relationship suggested by con- ventional (model A) thinking. As a result, the relative size of the fertility
 -14- and mortality reductions produced by a program of the sort advocated by UNICEF would depend on the program's structure and implementation. When only the fertility impact of mortality decline per se is considered, there is, as argued earlier, no basis for believing that the amount of fer- tility reduction associated with a given mortality decline might vary from measure to measure. Under an assessment based solely on the indirect fer- tility effect of mortality reduction measures, it would be reasonable to expect roughly the same population growth impact from a given amount of infant mortality reduction, regardless of whether that reduction were produced by, say, a GOBI, an FFF, or a total GOBI-FFF effort. This would no longer be the case when direct effects are also considered. For, as just described, there are grounds for suspecting that the direct fer- tility effect of the GOBI-FFF program efforts can vary greatly, depending both on the mix of components and upon how the selected mix of components is imple- mented (whether, for example, immunization programs are introduced more as technology delivery or as education efforts). If this is so, the population growth implications of, say, a GOBI program could well differ from those of some other mix of GOBI-FF program components - such as a "FIGO," "BIFFO," or some other such effort. This variability provides program designers with an opportunity to create component mixes that will vary not only with respect to their effectiveness in reducing mortality but also respect to the ratio of fertility to mortality reduction achieved and thus with respect to the amount of change in population size produced. Equitable Development Measures A prominent feature of population discussions during the 1970s was atten- tion to the clemographic implications of faster and more equitable development.
 -15- Particular interest was expressed in development's fertility effects, an interest that produced material ranging in tone from the thoughtful presen- tations of such authors as James Kocher, Robert McNamara, and William Rich to the strident claims that 'development is the best contraceptive" expressed at the 1974 Bucharest World Population Conference.&2./ For all the important dif- ferences in tone, however, such discussions generally led toward the common conclusion that more rapid and more egalitarian development could produce faster fertility decline. They can usefully be stated in closing, as two propositions intended to serve both as interim guides to action and as hypotheses to be confirmed or dispro- ven through future research. Proposition one is that when both their direct and indirect effects on mortality and fertility are appropriately taken into account, most policies and programs undertaken for the purpose of reducing mortality will in most settings and over the long run produce greater fertility than mortality declines and thus slower population growth and a smaller population size than would otherwise occur. The proposition maintains, in other words, that the currently-prevailing view that mortality reduction will normally lead to faster long-term growth is incorrect, an artifact of inadequate model specificiation. This proposition is based on two considerations which, if correct, mean that the normal overall outcome of mortality reduction measures will be a reduction in long-term growth ranging in magnitude from modest to quite large.

Thus, the strength of a direct fertility reduction effect needed to "tip the balance" from faster to slower growth would be modest in most cases. Even the immediate virtual elim- ination of infant mortality, for example, would in a typical developing country produce a stable population no more than 5% or so above that produced by a normal progression; and as can be seen from the material on child-spacing presented in annex III, even the modest fertility change represented by the inter-generational effects of a six-month extension of birth intervals is ade- quate to offset fully a 15% reduction in infant and child mortality. The second consideration is that most effective mortality reduction efforts could be expected to exercise at least some direct effect on fer- tility. In some cases, especially those involving social and economic mea- sures like the "general development" and "income distribution" cases discussed above, this direct effect is likely to be very large and the resulting restraint on future population expansion quite dramatic. In others, suich as targetted immunization programs, it might be much smaller; and there will no doubt be at least be some instances where it will be negligible or non- existent, in which the modest increases in growth suggested by model A might well result. Cassen, which serves as the basis for the income distribution illustration, is an extension of work on redistribution and growth initiated at the World Bank. The question posed concerns the mor- tality, fertility, and population growth effects of movement toward a more egalitarian pattern of income distribution. Dyson, Bell, and Cassen explore this question through the use of a simu- lation model. It features a division of the population under observation into three groups by income: the top 20%, the middle 40%, the bottom 40%. The economy as a whole is assumed to grow at 5% annually from a starting average per capita income of $100 (in 1970 dollars), with the gain distributed among the three income groups according to two alternate scenarios. Under the first, termed "constant shares," the income shares of the top, middle, and lower groups would remain fixed at their initial levels of 0.64, 0.28, and 0.08, respectively, typical of low income, high inequality countries. Under the second, called "changing shares," the income shares of the three groups would shift over time from the same initial distribution until, upon the attainment of a per capita income of $300, they would approximate the pattern of an egalitarian Eastern European country, with the top 20% of the population receiving 33% of the national income, the middle 40% receiving 40%, and the bottom 40% receiving the remaining 27%. That distribution would remain constant therafter. The level and distribution of national income thus deter- mined define the per capita income of each income group of the population for each time period covered by the projection; and this per capita income serves as the basis for defining the fertility and mortality levels of each group. These fertility and mortality levels in turn determine each population group's growth rate; and the weighted sum of the growth experienced by the three groups represents the growth of the society as a whole. At the end of each projection period, people are redistributed among income groups so that the initial 20:40:40 size distribution is maintained despite differences in group- specific growth rates. The relationship between per capita income on the one hand and fertility and mortality on the other is fixed by empirically derived equations of a cur- vilinear form. The simplest of the approaches taken, which are featured in the present example, are of two sorts. At low levels of income, the Taiwan time-series equations produce a significantly greater change in mortality and fertility per unit of income increase that do the international cross-sectional equations. doc.repnme: Mortality reduction, fertility decline, and population growth : toward a more relevant assessment of the relationships among them
doc.abstracts: This discussion responds to the questions of programs to reduce mortality and of how large a change in growth will result from efforts to lower fertility. It considers the influence of the policies or programs in question on mortality and on fertility, and the influence of the resulting fertility or mortality decline on the rate of change in the other. An approach of the sort required to adequately assess these policies or programs is difficult to apply, but its potential significance for policy and program analysis can be illustrated through a few qualitative and crude quantitative examples. These illustrations suggest two propositions to serve as interim guides to action and as hypotheses to be confirmed or disproven through future research. First, most programs and policies undertaken to reduce mortality will produce even larger fertility declines and thus slower growth. And, second, most measures designed to reduce fertility will also result in slower growth, but by an amount that may be significantly less than anticipated on the basis of conventional assessment techniques.
